text: Black as my soul and just as bitter, Midnight Hoppyness is a textbook Black IPA for me. Pours an opaque shade of black. Charred malt, coffee, dark bitter chocolate, and hint of peppery rye in the malt profile. Citrusy, grassy, piney, earthy, and floral notes coming from the hops. Its identical on the nose and palate. Viscous texture and the bitterness is very intense. This IPA is heavy, strong, and slightly spice from the rye. It blew me away.

I love it when black IPAs use their maltiness to tame aggressive pine bitterness. Not a particularly balanced beer, but if pine is your hop flavor of choice, this ones for you.Tried at the Cask Republic with Sabrandy and Ryan in 2017.
Bottle at Titans. Lovely, light roast, bit of malty sweetness, pine, bitterness, light citrus. Very nice. Chocolate. So smooth. Alcohol hidden.

Bottle/Fest.

A- Pine, citrus.

A- Dark brown color, dark liquid, tan head.

T- Pine, bitter, mild spice.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, bitter finish.

O- Lots of pine in this one. Almost overpowers everything else. A touch of black pepper and spice from the rye but not a lot.

Bottle at Titans. Citrus nose, chocolate, light coffee, nice. Great balance, good chocolate flavor, pine, citrus, peppery finish. You get a little spice from the rye as well. This is a very big beer and while not quite as good as a couple others in the field, quite excellent all around.
Bottled. Thick black beer with a big foamy tan head. Aroma is chocolate, pine, caramel. Very bitty, some grassy hops, sticky and thick. Not bad, not my preferred style.
Blackish pour with a tan head that lasts.Aroma of grapefruit, citrus, resin, chocolate, rye, caramel. Medium bodied, moderate bitterness, smooth mouth feel, alcohol hidden well.

22oz bottle. Frothy medium tan head atop cola black body. Aroma is moderately sweet, pine/grapefruit, some roast, earthy, bittersweet chocolate. Taste is moderately sweet, pine, roast, some earthy/grapefruit, light bittersweet chocolate. Medium-full body, some resin.
what a beer!!! A black IPA with hints of chocolate and smooth porter qualities. This is a heavy hitter but so easy to drink. A little too easy.....

650 ml bottle. Pours black with a full light tan head. Aromas of piney hops, chocolate, and creamy roasted malts. Flavors follow same with more dry chocolate and lots of pine. Unbalanced and a little thin. Good. Great - no...
650ml bottle, pours a deep dark brown. Nose subtle caramel and vegetal notes. Flavour earthy, hoppy, and herbal. Meh.
Tasting at MattsBlack color, small frothy head. Aggressive aroma of roasted malts and resiny hops. Good body, strong roasted malt flavor, resiny hops. Classic strong Black IPA.
December 1st bottling. Would be better fresher. Pours a black colour with a tan head. Aroma of cocoa and piney hops. Tastes chocolately, with a lasting bitterness. Pretty good considering the age.

This has dark brown colour, thin head. The aroma is hoppy, light fruit, and a fair bit of black patent. A lot of hoppy character, a fair bit of bitterness, sweet dark malts. Big body. Good balance. Ultimately this isnt that exciting, its just a good, straightforward black IPA.

Black pour, 2 fingers + of mocha. Nose is flowers and blackened malt. Bittersweet, leaning bitter. Middle is coffee, dark kilned malt, healthy dose of wood, coco. Finish is bittersweet and nicely balanced.

650ml bottle from Appalachian Vintners. Black pour with a brown head. Aroma has ash, raisins, cocoa and pine. Taste is of sweet cocoa, pine, ashy roast, light raisins and caramel with hints of dark chocolate. Blend is very good. Medium to full bodied. Little alcohol presence. Finishes well blended between bitter and sweet. If ashy. Very nice example of style. Not surprising from Knee Deep. 14.6

Jet black, huge brown head. Huge hops.... Soapy, and piney, with alot of chocolatey roast, and a super silky mouth feel. Medium bitterness, slightly fruity, and very pine resin hop finish. Nice black IPA, but Ive had better, not sure why its this highly rated.

Really fortunate to have stumbled upon this! However this bottle may be past its prime. Bottled 2/1/16. Almost opaque pour with dark burgundy edges. Sandy, billowing head settling to a compact cap. Roasty nose, dark chocolate, faded floral hops and grapefruit. Flavor has some nice chocolate and coffee bean, still some hop resin to balance, a bit of candied lemon and tart grapefruit gently on the cacao, espresso-centric linger. Still finishes dry though. The rye really adds an undesirable attribute to a black IPA, for me. The chocolate, hop resin, and feisty rye bite dont exactly meld together seamlessly. I love Knee Deep, but this one really got me to question the permeable line between a "hoppy American porter" and "black IPA"

Aroma is toasted malts, earthiness , grapefruit and citrus. Taste is deep roasted malts, licorice, tanins, and a light earthiness. Well balanced overall. Appearance is black with a medium beige head that retains quite well with a frothy lattice.
Pours a motor oil black, aroma is piney hoppy roasty flavors are piney, citrus, coffee as well. Delicious

On tap at the brewery 
Pours clear dark brown with a small beige head, good lacing. Aroma of grapefruit and pine, mild toasted malts. Flavor of grapefruit, caramel and pine <bri
Good bipa

22 oz bottle. Bottled on 01/21/15. From some store in Honolulu, HI. 
Dark brown color with a small tan head.
The aroma is roasted malt, licorice, mild alcohol, hops, bitterness and some dryness. 
The flavor is roasted malt, hops, bitterness, licorice and some dryness. 
Nice beer! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Nice aroma of hops, citrus, pine and roasted malt. Beautiful black body with generous head. Flavor is pines, light citrus and hops, light chocolate and a touch of bitter coffee. Nice mouthfeel that is easy, with a little carbonation but soft enough and quaffable.

Very large 3+ inch head if very dense and creamy bubbles. Something you would expect out of a good porter or stout and not a IIPA. Light milk chocolate, pine, band-aids and sweet malts in the aroma. Color is a very dark brown. Very delicious. Moderate malts and dry grains up front with a decent bitterness then mellows out to a nice roastyness, bitter chocolate and grassy hops. Lingering burnt toast and herbal notes. Moderate alcohol presence. Finishes dry and bitter and burnt. Maybe a bit of the rye lingers on the tongue to leave the dry chalkiness. A pretty good black IPA.  The perfect brew to drink after 4 weeks of drinking crappy beer in India.

Restrained aroma in a jet black pour. Laid back hop forward balance with tasty hints of coffee, licorice, and vanilla. Finish is nice and clean and leaves one wanting another. A very well done beer as its strength is totally hidden.
Black,tan head.Musty piney hop nose..Medium bodies piney spicy hop profile,lightly roasted.Long hop bitterness in finish. Needs more roast

22 oz bottle from Hoboken Vine. Dark brown-black with fairly heavy, spotted lacework. Pine and resiny hops, some toast / burnt malts. Not much sweetness, more of a citrus and pine flavor up front leading to a dry, pine bitterness and burnt notes on the close. Bit of earthy flavor as well. Soft to average carbonation. Pretty nice, tasty stuff.

Bottle: Poured a clear dark black color ale with a large dark color head with good retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of green hoppy notes with light citrus flavours and some dry roasted malt. Taste is a nice mix of dry roasted malt with some green citrusy hoppy notes with medium bitter finish. Body is a bit light for style with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol notes. Not a big fan of the style but this one was quite enjoyable.

Bottle pours out almost pitch black with a moderate tan head. Aroma is of burnt toast, grapefruit hops, some pine, cocoa, soy, cola. Taste is complex, nice hop profile, some citrus, grapefruit, light pine, chocolate, toast, mild coffee notes and some light soy sauce.
Bottle into pint glass. Pours a jet black with brownish head. Aroma is dank and citrusy. Taste is jammy with a little roastiness on the finish.
Pours black with tan head. Has a nice citrus hop and roasted malt aroma. A nice mix of flavors with citrus hop, chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts. Very carbonated and dry grainy aftertaste.
Bottle from City Beer, thanks Eddan. Black with a creamy tan head. A bit on the sweet side with licorice, roasted malt, chocolate and some hops. The finish was bitter.
@ best western americania 16-3-4: en trevlig Black ipa med gräsig humle och lena rostade toner.

Pleasant citrus, pine aroma. Appearance is black with a tan head. Flavor has a great hop flavor with notes of pine with notes of citrus. Roast is present. Mouthfeel is medium with a medium level of carbonation. Overall, this is a great black IPA. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

650 ml bottle from Canada Craft club. Aroma: grapefruits, roasted malt, chocolate. App: dark brown almost black with nice medium brown head and great lacing. Taste and palate: medium to full body, pretty smooth, impressed on how this can be that smooth, medium sweetness, light to medium bitter finish. Overall: pretty impressed. Even though this is a 99 overall I wasnt really thinking that I would like it. The 100 ibu and the high abv made me think it would be just like a big bomb of everything but in fact this is really made. We cant taste the alcohol (though our body feels it after a bottle of this beer), cant taste the really high ibu. This is proof of a really made beer. Great job guys!

Je dois avouer que je suis un peu étonné par par le présent 99 sur RateBeer. Pas que ce soit mauvais, mais ça na rien de très original, ni de vraiment fantastique. Limpression en bouche est très réussie, mais les saveurs sont plutôt quelconques. Le style se tient parfaitement cela dit, on goûte autant la torréfication des grains que la touche des houblons... Mais le tout pourrait être mieux. Clairement pas dans mes black IPA préférées.

Mise à jour : je monte tout de même ma note car je navais même pas remarqué quil sagissait dune bière à 9.5% ABV!! Assez exceptionnel comment lalcool est bien dissimulé!
Bomber from ABV. Pours a jet black color with a large beige head. A light resin and chocolate nose. Big sweet chocolate, ash, resinous sweet citrus hops, light spicy rye. This is awesome. Delicious.

Pours two fingers of tan head on a dark brown body.
The aroma is roasted malt, licorice, spice and earth.
The taste is rye at first, deep lemon bitter, some pine and finishes with some heat.
The texture is smooth.
This is great.

Bottle to tulip
Consummation: Soy brewed spruce tips.
Adjunct: Full on bitterness, booziness, vegetal and sappy notes.

Whee! Beer after disintegrating a wooden ping pong ball. Very cool unique aroma that Im sure I wont even describe with even a drop of accuracy. Penguins, eggplants, #2 robertson stubby screwdriver, salad tongs. In the background one can find dark chocolate, pine, sweaty feet, sawdust, dried raspberries, faint coffee filter. Thats all pretty interesting. Flavour is quite different but pure dark and pine. Milk chocolate, orange or lemon or tacos, roast that doesnt get in the way, spice, the rye goodness, creaminess in between the bitter beat down. Enjoyed this all the way through even with knowing that a 7 kg donair sits on my kitchen counter.
An excellent black IPA! Black pour with a foamy tan head. A ton of lacing. Big notes of bitter hops, pine, and a big malt presence of course. Exceptionally balanced and very tasty.

650ml bottle pours almost black in color with a generous tan head that leaves some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is grapefruit with some light roasted grains and caramel. Taste is a grapefruit and herbal hop bitterness with some roasted grains and a caramel malty sweetness. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, a very nice DIPA that is hop forward and quite tasty. Definitely recommended.

A bit of a low fill 22oz bomber pours with a dark body that supports a big tall fancy mocha colored head that leaves behind some spotty lacing. The moderate strength aroma offers up dark roasted malts a bit of chocolate malts and then some inviting hoppy notes like earthy spicy notes, some citrus and a dash of a grassy sensation. The first few sips are good gravy good. I get dark roasted to burnt malts flowing quickly into bitter grassy hops, a perfect spike of citrus and then some pine hops and an earthy slightly spicy sensation. Man. This is doing the trick. Lovely. It has hefty hoppy depth playing against dark roasted to burnt malts and chocolate yum. The slight knock I have is that the body is a tad thin compared to the other big luscious players in this style space.
22oz bottle in a snifter. Black with large tan head, pine, molasses, pepper, chocolate nose. Sweet with a slightly dry finish, low carbonation. Long chocolate finish.
Fine blend of hops and malt. Aroma is herbal hops and roasted malt. One of better examples of style.

Bomber poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, geapefruit, dried fruit, coffee and light earthiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of roasted malt, cocoa, pine, light grapefruit and light earthiness with a smooth dry bitter lingering roasty finish.

Midnight hoppyness is a dark black brown brew with a firm head of tiny tan bubbles. Nose is rich roasted malt and resin. Taste is a nice blend of darkly roasted malt and evergreen hops that come together nicely. Body is lightly fizzy and smooth.

Shared with Strykzone on Facebook Chat. Poured very black with a big foamy tan head and lots of sticky lacing. Nose of roasted malts, chocolate, and dark fruit. Bold in body. The flavor is complex with citrus, some pineapple, dark fruit, plus I get the rye. The finish is bitter chocolate. Excellent stuff.

Bomber from Hayduke that we had together via facebook chat. Dark dark with a big tan head. A nice mix of roasted notes and west coast hop fruitiness. Some molasses. Some nice complexity is tasted early. Citrus is nice and there might be some zest. Tropical fruit. Bakers chocolate bitterness. Mid pour the chocolate grows and is almost fudge. Toward the finish more roasted notes and coffee emerge. At the last sip I got some alcohol but it was very well hidden. This was quite nice. If I had a knock it would be that there might be more flavor available with such a high ABV. Good stuff, though.

650ml bottle enjoyed @ my vacation apartment. Pours blacker than black with a thick and creamy beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, citrus, chocolate and nuts. Flavour is medium bitter, roasted and balanced sweetness. Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation. Finish is roasted and well balanced bitterness.

Draft at Owl Farm with Erica on Sunday, 05.10.2015. Pours dark (bar was also dark), tan or brown head. Characteristics typical of a black IPA but without the all-too-common burnt-toast layer. Enjoyed the hops and roasty, slightly chocolatey malts without feeling like Id just smoked 2 packs of cigs. Light-medium mouthfeel.

On tap @ Knee Deep. Black in color with a tan head. A lot of roasted malt and a lot of citrus peel hop character. Nice grapefruits and pine. Sorta herbal, too. Good bitterness on the tongue. A lot of roast, pine, herbs, and citrus rind. Nice grapefruit and a touch of orange. Big time roast and coffee. Decent enough black IPA.
On tap at District Tap House. Bold orange body with medium head. Nose is citrus, honey and lots of hops. Taste is crisp, cactus. Sticky texture. Nice bite.
Super dark, mostly malty, shocked by the 100 IBU rating. Have enjoyed everything by these guys and this is no different. Solid representation of the style but not world-class.

Got this on a flight at the brewery. $6 for a flight of 4x 5 oz doubles and triples. Thank you Jesus. 

Everything you might expect from a double black IPA. Full bodied, malt finish, notes of chocolate and coffee. Hops have a nice bite. Great IPA. 

- Snowboards and IPA

Shared bomber, poured to snifters displaying a mahogany highlighted, brown tone, with a presentable & persistent layer of mahogany tan head froth, and good cling to the spots & streaks of lacing. The nose was roasted, malty, and creamy, with chocolate notes, and light spice. Medium+ bodied, with fair carbonation, the taste included a moderate hop bitterness that was earthy, roasted and dry, smoothed by some pleasant creaminess to the mouthfeel that also blanketed my perception of abv. Robust & flavorful, but more as a rye Stout to me.

Aromas of floral hops, buttery hops, pines, caramel latte, chocolate, resinous hops and subtle dark rye. Appearance is black with heavy brown lacing against the glass. Taste complex with heavy dark rye bread, rye spice, chocolate and resinous hop bitterness overtones. More subtle notes of prune juice, blackberries, plums, raisins, grapefruit, orange, dark roasted malts, black grain malt, coffee and toasted bread. Finishes very dank with a lot of resinous, bitter hops and noticeable booze. Overall, this is very nice with a lot of flavor. One of the more rye forward rye beers Ive had. Very nice blend between dark ale and IPA. Heavy on the pines and dank hops. A rating.
22 ounce bottle provided by Matt .. . Pours a deep brown .. Mild road and a rounded bitterness .. Decent black thing .. . Wilson is senile

Bottled. Pour into a tulip, porter Black with a creamy light tan head. Aroma is lots of roasted malts and chocolate up front and lots of citrus in the background. Flavor is again, very roasted, lots of chocolate. Huge roasted Stout character here. Bittering hops, some lemon, pineapple. Hop bitterness finish. Full bodied. The malt and the hops blend so well. Its just amazing. Really good.
on tap,poured into a tulip glass..jet black with a big fluffy white head..aroma of hops,spices,roasted nuts..hoppy,roasty,spicy..very good.

On tap at the River Room, Whole foods boise Dark brown black with tan head and thick heavy lacing. Lots of bitter roasted flavors and aromas. Strong piney bitterness. Clean finish with lingering roasted bit. Nice and bold CDA
Poured into a pint glass. Pours very dark brown almost black with small tan head that quickly disapears. Smell of sweet citrus hops. Has a slight bitterness in the taste especially at the back end.

Black pour with small tan head.
Sticky oily hops and nicely roasted malts
Roasty mild body.. booze is well hidden..
Very nice black IPA like Wooky Jack

22 oz. bottle from The Hop Yard, Raleigh, NC. Dark brown pour with a creamy tan head. Aroma of grapefruit, mango, and tangerine with subtle dark chocolate notes. The taste is an awesome blend of chocolate and coffee with bold citrus and floral hops notably grapefruit rind, pineapple, and fresh roses. Finish is perfect; none too bitter from either the roasted malt or hop bitterness but lingers just long enough. Great beer!
Draft at Moor Pat, Williamsville, NY. Fuller bodied black pour, Roasted dark malts, dark chocolate, solid bitterness. well balanced, nice
Draft at Imbibe Wine. Nose is pine resin, citrus, and a light coffee mocha effect. Clear dark brown with a medium beige head. Flavor is mildly bitter with some malty coffee.

Draft at Rattle n Hum with Streets. Pours a deep blackish brown body with thin off white lacing. Aroma is sweet roast and very subtle pine hop. Mouthfeel is medium to light-bodied. Flavors consist of sweet roast, lots of sugar, faint pine hop and a touch of grapefruit - but the hops in this one are super subdued.
Dark brown color. Big mouth with lots of fudge, roasted malt and ample hops to back things up. Well balanced. Fairly agressive hop, but hops dont really shine.

66 cl bottle @ tiong, bottled 10.07.2014
Aroma has fruity hops, gooseberry bush and grapefruit. Flavour has licorice, nettles and gooseberry bush notes. Also some licorice. A black IPA on the hoppy side. Hides the alcohol and roastiness very well. Feels fresh and strong on hops; perhaps a bit unbalanced though.

650 ml bottle. Pours a pitch black colour with a beige head. Aroma of rich citrusy bitterness, floral notes, some chewy grapefruity and herbs. Rich flavour of rich citrusy bitterness, chewy grapefruit, rich roastiness, pine, orange peel, bread and grass. Full bodied and thick mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Very fresh and strong. Pretty much a mix of a double IPA and a black IPA. I havent tasted anything like this before I think. This isnt the first time Knee Deep has surprised me. Great stuff.

65 cl bottle.
Pours pitch black color with a small beige head. Very intense piney aroma, resinous hops, some caramel and mild malts. Grapefruits and cocoa on the flavor, some wooden notes too. Very nice.
5316

650ml bottle from Whole Foods Columbus Circle, New York @ Varjopikkujoulut
Bottled 10/17/14 - 
Pours pitch black with a smooth white head. Intense aroma of fresh herbal hops, grass, pine, citrus, some roastiness. Taste is hoppy, grassy and herbal with loads of fruits, pine, resin and some roastiness. Finish is hoppy, fruity and grassy with loads of pine, resin, hints of rye and slight roastiness in the finish. Complex, heavy and fruity with loads of flavor. Feels like a double IPA with just a hint of roastiness. Great stuff.

Draft at Barrel Republic. Pours very dark brown with a creamy, bubbly light brown head. Smells like sweet, tangy raisin, burnt grains, some sweet chocolate, and strong slightly astringent booze. Tastes like chocolate, booze, tangy raisin, burnt toast, and very roasted malt.
Draft. Pours black. Aroma and taste are citrus, piney, and some roasted malts.

A bottle that Ive been slowing looking around for a while and found at Brewers Haven in Boise. Seemed like a good choice to add into the Halloween lineup. Very dark brown pour, topped with a finger of creamy brown head. Pine, citrus and heavy roast makeup a potent aroma, strong and inviting. Heavy roast in the flavor, but a heavy dose of citrus brings the hops forward. Light pine. Picking up the rye very minimally and just in the tail. A very nice brew.
From a 22 oz bottle shared in Avon NC. Pours black with a massive tan head. Citrus nose. Flavors of grass, oranges and tobacco notes. Bitter finish.

22oz bottle, thanks to alexsdad06 for sharing! Date on the label is 2/27/14... Black color, thin tan head. Leaves good splotches and ropes of lace. Roast malt, dark chocolate, dark wheat, rye, earthy bitter hop. Nice pine. Bigger bitter taste, a little astringent, lighter sweet. Light bit of alcohol heat but nothing out of line for the ABV. Pretty assertive overall. Bigger body, kind of a creamy thicker sort of chewy texture. Lighter carbonation. Light slick finish, more dry taste at the end. Overall, enjoyable stuff, but I feel itd be much better fresh... I can tell that theres a lot of potential here, I think a fresh sample would be much less astringent & have much more hop aromatic.
Pitch black, slightly tan head. Plenty of lacing. Earthy hops and malty. Awesome brew.

22 oz bottle shared with DrSilverworm and Anthony. Pours dark brown to black in color with a medium sized, creamy beige head. The aroma and flavor have roasted malt, some spicy rye character, piney hops, some faded hop character comes through a bit as this was bottled on 2/27/14, I dont know if I would have purchased this if I saw that. Its good, but I think it is past its prime.
Tap @ The Doolittle: Dark brown with a light brown head that sticks around for a long time. Sharp citrusy aroma with freshly cut grass. Hoppy flavor with a roasted malt finish. Quite tasty.

Poured from bomber. Near black with robust tan head. Minimal lacing. Dank nose that concentrates around notes of roasted malt and cut grass. Pine and orange bloom behind. It works and I like it. There. Taste starts creamy, recalling roast and light chocolate( with subtle chalkiness), before moving into a sharp field of grassy hops and spiced tropical breads (that a thing, right?). Stays on the bitter end of things through finish. Solid mouthfeel and high abv never a distraction. Well executed and enjoy.

Bottle at home purchased in Allendale MI. Pours jet black with a persistent ten head. Aroma is roasty and alight chocolate with a pine presence. Very nice beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. The pour is dark. The aroma is hops cutting through. The taste is a very solid black ipa, hops are prominent and the dark beer comes through nicely. Well done

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
65cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2012, thx alot to Dirk for sharing!, complex bitter brew, bitter/malty/roasted and slightly woody/spicy, very balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew
Bottle - Roasty malts, chocolate and huge pine notes. Jet black with a rich brown head. Roast, coffee, chocolate and pine hops. Lots of roast and good huge hops to balance. Big beer, but great.

Pours a really dark black color with a thick dark mocha colored head. With a ton of retention the head sticks around like crazy. A nice wavy lacing. A creamy feel right upfront is the first thing I notice. A very interesting beer. A bitter coffee flavor is the starter here. A decent rye bitterness makes an appearance. A very smooth and creamy brew. Very interesting. The abv is very hidden be careful.
"A very well balanced and full imperial black ipa. Orange peel, spruce, roasted malt, molasses and coffee. Hard to believe this is the abv it is it is so well integrated. Not too shabby :)"
Sample at Suds on the Shore. Pours black with an off-white head. Hops, dark roasted malt smokiness in the aroma and taste. Nice black IPA.
Bomber from my special brother..thx g! Shared with hakes dr.. black pour..killer beer ..hopps ..bitter..long lasting aftertaste... love it

I found this beer to be very average and not special in anyway. The hops were flat and the malts seems overly burnt in flavor. I will be trying this beer again to make sure I didn't just get a defective product.
Flaske: En af de bedste Black IPA jeg har fået. Kulsort øl med et flot skumhoved. Duften er superlækker blød tropisk. Smagen er slet ikke ristet. Sort IPA i denne udgave er ganske hæderlig. God øl.

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 5/7/2014. Pours dense pitch black color with a 2 finger dense and rocky tan head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, lemon zest, orange peel, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, spicy rye, dark bread, floral, grass, pine, and floral/roasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of bright citrus/pine hops and dark/roasted malt sweetness; with good strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, lemon zest, orange peel, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, spicy rye, dark bread, floral, grass, pine, and floral/roasted earthiness. Good amount of pine/grassy/roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, lemon zest, orange peel, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, spicy rye, dark bread, floral, grass, pine and floral/roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity, balance, and robustness of bright citrus/pine hops and dark/roasted malt sweetness; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and fairly creamy/sticky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome imperial black IPA! All around great complexity and balance of bright citrus/pine hops and dark/roasted malt sweetness; and very smooth and crisp to sip on for the big ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

Draft at brewery. A moderate roast in the nose with some grassiness. Taste is like a chocolate/coffee combo. Short of a harsh roastiness. Quite pleasant and I am not a fan of this style. Light citrus and grass in the flavor from the hops. good.
Bottle to pint glass. Nice citrus and resin jump out of the glass. Black with brown head. Flavors of deep citrus with not too much roast. Nice.

Bottle from Champanes, 
this ale had a dark brown / black pour and gave a large, foamy coffee cream colored bubbled cover that receded a bit and left a sticky ring, it left nice lacing on the glass, 

it had aromas of roasted malt, grapefruit like citrus and grass hops, a little coffee and faint caramel, the roasted malt and citrus hops were out front on the nose, 

the flavors were roasted malt with grapefruit citrus hops, a little caramel and coffee with some malt sweetness, 
the finish had a good citrus hop bitterness with some roasted malt bitterness and malt following, 

the mouth feel was light to medium that was creamy on the lips and it had average carbonation, 

I thought this was a good typical black ipa, it was a nice drink.

Jet black and topped with a thick, khaki head and smelling deeply of roasted nuts and and toasted caramel. Lace is thick and sticky and supported by a heavy, black liquid; lightly bitter and slightly salty. Glides over my tongue and coats the inside of my mouth with a buzzy creaminess that is as enjoyable as I have experienced.
This Midnight is going to be a favorite for a long time coming. I love everything about it and am looking forward to finding it again, very soon!
Roasty and very bitter, very 2004, tons of roast and booze. Tons of alcohol burn, LAME
Bottle. Pours black with brown head. nose/taste of toasted pine, roast chocolate, mocha pie, toasted grass and earthy chocolate. Medium bodied.

Bomber purchased at BevMo in Carmel Mountain ($7.69). Pours an inky black color with a full three fingers of tan-brown foam with good retention. AROMA is mostly of hops (pine, dank hops, citrus) with a bit of rye bread and charred malts. FLAVOR of dark roasty malts (hint of cocoa), nice citric hops, spicy rye, and pine sap. Hops beat out the roast in the nose, but the flavor has a good balance between the hops and roast. Finishes with moderate bitterness and some lingering roastiness and sweet citrus. A good and balanced take on the style. (51, 868)
Thick black color nice head minimal lacing very pleasant aroma with a nice thick bitter taste
Awesome black IPA. Although, it tastes more like a stout than an IPA. The IPA aromas really come through, though. Its awesome

Draft at original gravity, poured black small to medium head. Aromas are pussy, dank hops, oats. Flavor is the same with pineapple, grapefruit, and dark and roasty malt. Overall this is awesomely hoppy for the appearance.

Thankfully my sister in law saw this. Had it on tap. Pours dark with a nice creamy head. Aroma of nice hops. 9.5% of hoppy deliciousness!! This beer is awesome!!

Revere Stryker dog!

22 oz. bottle, pours black as night with a finger-width of tan head. Nose brings out pillowy roasted malt, some soft dry cocoa powder, and moderate woody hops. Flavour is a delicate balance of roasted malt and piney hops, with perhaps the roast slightly winning out. Nice and dry, with a woody and roasty palate, finishing on notes of roasted malt and lots of piney hops - light-to-moderate astringency for the style. Excellent by-the-books black IPA that gets a bit sweet and malty the more you drink.

Has a good nose for a black IPA, with a nice bit of hops and some good malt. The initial taste is pretty malty. The mouth feel is smooth and full bodied. Ends with a nice rye-hop bite that most black IPAs lack. One of the better black IPAs Ive had.
Black pour from 22oz bottle. Graham cracker, rye, malts, chocolate, bitter and hoppy. Very tasty.

Thanks to my lovely wife for hauling this bottle back from her vacation...err, work trip to San Diego. On second hand, screw that. Its only my due for being left here in the harsh Minnesota cold. Split with aforementioned wife. 

The pour is very dark & very carbonated, with light leading bloody around the top eight inch or so of the brew. Nose is that distinctly unnatural marriage of roast & piney hops with a sideswipe of Hersheys Kiss. Not bad, but light. 

Midnight Hoppyness probably made early parole. Wild mix of roast, sweet malts, piney hops, & after all that marches by the parade stand, theres a blast of earthy, spicy rye. At the exact moment of rye detonation theres a hump of bitterness: the finish is a tumbling shaker of everything trying to shout at the top of its lungs for my tongues attention. Smoothness on the palate contrasts with the edged weapon of the chaotic neutral taste bombardment. I was just told Im "sucking this down" & indeed my wife has twice as much left as I do. Pace yourself, max. 

The wild-eyed madness of this brew tickles my fancy & the rye tickles my happy sack; this is an excellent joining of ingredients that arent easy to meld into an excellent beer: but Knee Deep has succeeded. Thanks dear!

Draught at Stone World Bistro Liberty Station, San Diego. Pitch black beer with a nice lasting beige/brownish head. Hoppy chocolate aroma, grassy, citrus, grapefruit, licorice, hay, some cocoa. Hoppy pine flavor, chocolate, cocoa, grassy, citrus, floral, some licorice. Nice Black IPA.

4/12/14. Appearance is dark with a tan khaki head. Aroma is dark fruits. Taste is dark fruits and smokiness. Finishes dry and bitter. Would never guess that this one is over 100 OBUs. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle. Drank 4/12/14. Pours to a deep black color with a medium tan head. Aroma has notes of sweet & hops with a mild alcohol scent, light roasted malts too. Taste has some similar notes to the aroma with slight dark fruit notes & a medium bitter finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at Taps in Petaluma. Pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Nice smooth flavor with some strong hoppiness at the end.

Sample at the Ale Wine & Spirits beer tasting on 04/03/2014: Brownish-black color with a medium creamy beige head that recedes gradually. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, hops and pine. Medium to full body with flavors of resiny hops, roast malt and subtle dark chocolate. The finish is roasty with a piney hops aftertaste. Solid Black IPA all around.

> Solid grilled fruit, chocolate cake Black IPA
[ Bottle ][ Whole Foods Encinitas ][ 22oz ][ $7 ][ Alesmith Snifter Tulip ][ 3/25/14 ]
>> Deep near black pour, thick mocha foam, rocky with great retention. Thick swathes of sticky lacing. Nose is grilled strawberry, dust, ash, grilled pineapple, strawberry chocolate cake. Palate is a bit dusty, bitter, not papery, mild spice. Probably not super fresh, but found in fridge and it seems to have held up.
>!< Too dusty, possibly not super fresh

Poured from a bomber into a pint glass a pitch black with a huge tan pillow top head that laces thickly down the sides.
Aroma is HUGE roasted barley with faint hops.
Flavor is uniquely caramel sweet for a black rye IPA. Grapefruit/resin is high with a roasted craziness at the finish. Do pick up some slight rye but more impressed with its balance of higher ABV with all that is going on within this brew. Will but a second bottle since I had to share this one...

Aroma: faint hop aroma. Boozy malt comes through. Would like a little more hop aroma from a DIPA. Appearance : beautiful deep dark black. creamy tan head faded after a few minutes leaving nice lacing. Taste: carbonation level feels perfect gives a nice creaminess. Good hop kick. Mildly spicy hop followed by slight grapefruit. Balanced level of malt that I like in a black ipaI although I?m not getting any of the rye character. No hiding the 9.5% but I?m not complaining. Overall. I enjoyed it but would have liked to taste more rye malt and have a little more hop aroma
Bomber bottle. Pours black, tan head. Not much of a hop aroma at all, tastes malt, cant taste much rye at all, bit of a bitter hop kick.

Bottle split at Bruces pad, big thanks to the CDA finder general - Ell Kay Ess, 16/01/14.
Light black with a big old tan head that thins and retains.
Nose is skunky hoppage, light roast, orange pithdom, earthy, cocoa, liqourice, ladies sweet armpit sweat, grapefruit.
Taste comprises skunked up hops, light Ribena berry, earthy, light cocoa, bitter tropicals, grapefruit trace, hint of boozedom.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, drying hop bitterness in the closure.
Fuck Yeah - top draw CDA !!!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 22 oz bottle poured into an oversized wine glass. Bottled date is 11/10/13. Pours a very dark brown with a foamy tan head, nice lacings. Aroma is very nice, roasted malts, grapefruit, papaya, tropical fruits but more on the sweet side. Taste is sweet up front, middle is roasted malts, some chocolate, coffee, then citrusy fruits but not over . powering. Very nice finish, overall a very good beer but it could use more hops at the end. Definitely will have this again.
Very good beer from Windy City. Dark, thick, wafting citrus hops. The citrus hops takes over the palate, then the roast builds.

Bottle thanks to Leighton. It pours darkest brown/near black with a medium tan head. The nose is roasted malt, toast, earth, juicy, cocoa, floral and potpourri and light citrus. The taste is soft roast, toast, earth, ash, pine, varnish, light citrus and a good deal of bitterness. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Smooth, flavoursome and well-rounded. Really rather great! A top-drawer black IPA.

Cheers to Leighton for yet another great BIPA. Pours very dark brown with a creamy and sticky tan head. Nose is chock full of big grassy hops with a generous dose of citric tang. Bold hops in front of sweet milk chocolate and toasty marshmallow. Good start. Taste takes the grassy hops up to the next level. Big grass and piney hop focus followed by a very zesty and tangy sweetness. Big mandarin here with a nice dose of peppery spice and dark chocolate. Coffee espresso-like bitterness on the finish. Lengthy and creamy mouth feel. Very, very good

16th January 2013Tasting at the pad of the ever gracious Bruce. Thanks to Leighton for this CDA. Opaque dark brown beer, good mid tan head. Palate is softish and airy. Very light carbonation. Smooth and mellow dark malt. Touch of bitterish coffee under soft dark malt cream. Nice light pine hops and a decent mellow citrus. Finishes soft with a mild bitter linger. Good balance of flavours here. Very drinkable.

Bottle shared in London - picked up in CA. Pours black-brown with a sturdy, creamy beige head. The nose has dark berries, torched earth, moderate cocoa. Medium sweet flavor with bitter dark chocolate, earth, burnt wood, faint alcohol, raisins, charred pine. Medium to full bodied with fine, creamy carbonation. Moderate resinous charred pine to finish, plenty of earth, bittersweet baking cocoa. Quite drinkable for the ABV. Good depth. Solid.

pours black with a dense one inch head that leaves sparce lacing. aroma is roasted malt with some dark chocolate and tobacco... just a hint of citrus good in the background( smells more like a porter). Taste is malt and rye at the front with some cocoa and hops in the background. very smooth drinker.. and hides the alcohol well. good beer, but more porter than IPA.

13 dec 2013, bottle. Dark brown/black. Nose is rye malt and grapefruit malt. Thin body, faintly oily, mildly fizzy. Sugary rye malt, some grapefruit hops. Pretty good for a rye ipa. Not too much rye bitterness, sweet enough, hops shine through. I like it 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Black pour, with a light tan head. Roasted malt, bitter hops, grapefruit, pineapple, citrus, espresso, and milk chocolate. A spot on black ipa, good stuff.

Pours a pitch black with a two finger kakhi head with excellent lacing. Aroma is of citrus, pine, spicy rye, tropical fruits, coco, tobacco, caramel, candied fruits, and some light soy. Taste is similar to the aeoma but also has some coffee, roasted malts, rye bread, cedar wood, and some molasses. Has. Medium full body with a creamy velvety mouthfeel and a semi dry, pretty bitter, long finish. Overall, a very tasty and complex double black IPA that hides its 9.5 ABV very well.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2014 Bomber. Pours black with a big fluffy head that fades slowly and leaves nice lacing. Great aroma of dark roast, chocolate, rye bread, pine, and tropical fruit. Taste is burnt rye bread mixed with pine needles and it tastes better than it sounds. Some underlying chocolate, coffee, citrus, and tropical fruit as well. Medium to thick body, very creamy mouthfeel with a little oiliness too. Great mix of styles here and its delicious.

Bomber from Valley Farms Market in Spring Valley, CA. This is a thick, hearty IPA with a black pour and brownish head. The rye comes through in the color and taste making this one of the best IPAs Ive found in some time.

GREAT BREW here folks. Score this one if you can find it. Dark black pour with brown tones. Amazing dark and tropical fruited malty nose with hints of molasses, hops, and rye. LOVED this nose. Like candy. Flavor is thick bringing out rye notes through the mid-palate, along with some toast, dark fruit, hints of dirt, and a nice hoppy bite at the end that continues on the tropical fruit side of things. Excellence.

Bomber from Bev4Less. Pours black as the name suggests. Nice aroma on the pour, ample light brown sugar head that hangs around. Aroma is a melange of coffee, chocolate, dark fruits (raisins, maybe) and soy sauce. Would love to know the malt bill on this one. Taste is clean and light relative to what the nose suggests. Still, complexity abounds, cocoa, tobacco, leather, and some sugary/fruity twinges, but nowhere near what was in the nose. Medium mouthfeel, lingers well on the tongue, without being too oily or cloying. Wildly drinkable, with ABV very well disguised. 3-4 bombers in I imagine it wouldnt be so hidden anymore. Really, really nice stuff!

Bottle. Black with a thick light tan head. Lots of lacing. Aroma is citrusy, earthy and some rye notes. Taste follows suit and the rye imparts some nice spice. Silky mouthfeel with good carbonation for balance. Very nice.

22oz bomber purchased from craftshack. Pours pitch black with a thin creamy tan head. Aroma of fresh juicy tropical fruit, light roasted malts, citrus skin, and a hint of green onion. Taste is of roasted malt, chocolate, bitter grapefruit, sweet pineapple, citrus skins, and pine. Awesome!

22oz bomber from Ed5388, thanks bald dog. Poured a silky black body with an average sized creamy beige head that has some nice lasting power to it. Aroma is great, burnt pineapple, burnt toast, raosted pineapple, darker chocolate. Great body, smooth yet thick with softer carbonation and a lingering thick aftertaste. Flavor is great, roasted pineapple, dark lightly burnt toast, cola, soy sauce, raosted citrus, some yellow grapefruit. Good good stuff.

Sampled at GABF. Pours an inky black with some beige head. Roasty nose, also pithy, pine, toast. Flavors of chocolate, coffee, pine, soap, citrus pith. Dry, chalky finish. The malt notes were a bit distracting.
On tap at GABF 2013, big malty bitter, big roasted malt taste and a big bitter finish, great black IPA.

650 ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours a nearly opaque black color with a big tan head that has good retention. The aroma is strong and overtly hoppy with fresh grapefruit and tangerines. The taste, like the aroma, is a big blast of fresh grapefruit, with some oranges, tangerines lifting. The malts base is mocha, earthy walnuts and chocolates but they are light and take a backseat to the hops. The palate is full with just a bit of chalkiness and the carbonation is lively. Finishes medium-long in duration. Overall: A really tasty black IPA. Well done Knee Deep.

S: A nice balance smell that shows pine, grapefruit, dark roasted malt, a hint of coffee and some tropical fruits. P: Black with a 2-3 finger brown head that refuses to settle down. T: Lots of grapefruit, and pine, some roasted malts, in the middle of the road, with a lemony finish. M: Light, somewhat sticky with low bitterness. O: Its alright, the finish seemed weird.
Pours coffee black, the aroma is hop-forward without any spicy rye notes. The West Coast hop treatment eclipses the rye characteristic I would expect in a rye IPA.

Bottle. Wow. When these guys hit, they hit hard. Pour is pitch black with a medium creamy brown head that dissipates with great lacing. Aroma is a citrus, grapefruit, pine, roasted malt, coffee blast. Yum. Flavor is the same, wonderful citrus notes, roasty coffee and some chocolate. Light sweet, light bitter. Medium body, oily texture. This may be my new favorite black IPA. Knee Deep is the shit!

Dark black in color.... Light tan head... Aroma of citrus, piney aromatic hops, roasted malts... Flavor is rich chocolate, fresh roast coffee is fairly prevalent, spice on the palate... Nice beer, one of my favorite black IPAs.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz. bottle. It pours a very black color with a nice tan head. The aroma is full of roasted malts balanced nicely with some tropical fruit, pineapple and peach mostly and pine. A little salty. The flavor is very roasted and bitter. Savory smoked meat with a silky mouthfeel from the rye malt. Not a ton of hop flavor except for the robust bitterness. A little pine in there and tropical fruit hiding in the background. A bit "in your face" and all over the place, but still an enjoyable drink. Thumbs up.

Bomber from The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours very brown/black with a slight dark tan head. Huge hop aroma. With a little dark malt. Hop seems resin/citrus. Lets call it full bodied. Theres a lot of dark malt, perhaps with a chocolate note. The hop is all over this. Moderate hop burn. Lots of citrus and pine for me. Knee Deep isjust... Knee Deep. Brilliant effing ale.

From fridge.. Very stout like pour.. Deep, dark brown, with a thin tan head. Initial aromas of light pine and grapefruit, with layers toasted grain, and spicy rye bread. On the palate, the flavors bounce between herbal hops, roasted grain, pine, chocolate, citrus rind and toasted bread. I love the complexity and layers! Nice bitterness, without being astringent. Mouthfeel is good, no complaints. As the beer warms, I believe the hop profile actually gains strength and length on the finish.. with a strong lingering herbal, pine, citrus rind finish, with pronounced, clinging bitterness... Definitely 100 IBU's. Solid. You got my vote. I hope this becomes year round. Well made.. Nice to see a black IPA that is actually represents an IPA. Hop heads buy with confidence. Seems to be best enjoyed chilled, though not cold. 

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

Bottle. Black beer with a brown head. Grapefruit and light earth aroma with light pine. Grapefruit and light cocoa flavor with light pine. Medium bodied. Grapefruit and light cocoa lingers with light caramel, light pine, and light earthiness.
On tap at Capitol Beer and Taproom, thin, brown head roasted aroma and flavor. The rye is definitely present but is fairly well balanced by the hoppy bitterness.
On tap at Capitol Beer, Sacramento. Pours black with a decent tan head and a pine aroma. There is a hearty rye malt flavor with some great hopping. Everything works quite well.
On tap at capitol beer Sacramento. Color is black with a brownish head. Taste is rye and pepper with lots of roasted malts. Aroma is very hoppy . Slight pungent taste as well.
wow . another exceptional brew from knee deep . Will buy plenty of this .
